text: A witness herein, acknowledged having been duly sworn and testified upon his oath as follows:
I do. DIRECT EXAMINATION
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Good morning, Dr. Howard.
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Good morning, Leah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you hear me all right?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Yes, I can.  How about you?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I can hear you just fine.
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: All right.  Good.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So can you please state your name for the record?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Yes, Thomas Peter Howard.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And my name is Leah McMorris, I represent the plaintiff in this case and I'll be taking your deposition this morning.  Where is it that you are located today?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: I'm in a court reporting office, which is in I think the address is Viera, Florida, but it's near my home in Melbourne, Florida.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is there anyone there with you?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Yes.  Yvette Harrison the court reporter is here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is your attorney there as well?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: No, he's on the phone.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm sitting in New Jersey.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: All right.
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: And I thank you for changing it for a phone dep, which is why I didn't have to go down there.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: And your attorney is -- I'm sorry, strike that. You are designated as a witness in this case at the request of General Electric and Westinghouse; is that correct?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: That's my understanding, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  No one else?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Not that I'm aware of, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And I don't think -- you've been deposed many times in the past, so I won't go through all of the general rules for a deposition.  But I just ask at any point you can't hear me or you don't understand my question, just let me know and I'll rephrase the question or speak up and make sure that you can hear me.  Is that fair?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Great.  Are you currently employed, Dr. Howard?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: I retired from the VA in 2017.  I certainly continued to do litigation consultation work, but I don't know if that satisfies your definition of employment. I'm retired from the VA.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often do you perform litigation consultant work?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: I review probably on average about two cases a week.  But if you're asking me about depositions and trial testimony, it's certainly less than that.  I think I'm estimating this is about the fifth deposition this year.  And on average I would think it ranges between five and ten the last few years at least. And then in trial I probably testify on average maybe once every year, maybe a little less than that recently.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What percentage of those cases are asbestos related cases?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, this year I would -- certainly the vast majority are asbestos related.  I'm working on one rather large tobacco litigation case, so that would be the only one right now that is not asbestos related.  I think it would probably be about 75 to 95 on an average basis over the last several years are asbestos related.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When were you initially contacted regarding the Drummond case?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, I have no independent recollection of a specific date, but based on my report I would estimate that it would have certainly been within a few weeks of September 2018.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what were you asked to do following your retention on this case?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, I'm again referring to my report, but usually as stated in my report I'm asked to be -- review records and deposition testimony as in this case and then to be willing to render either a report or testify in deposition usually about state of the art issues. Although, as a pulmonologist, frequently as in this case I was asked to review medical records and would expect to weigh in on medical issues as well.  So state of the art, medical issues. And then as noted in my report address the probability if you will of warnings changing the direction of Mr. Drummond's case.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So in addition -- it is my understanding you reviewed Mr. Drummond's deposition testimony in this case?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Yes.  I brought with me today what I reviewed, which I think is 11 volumes of deposition testimony.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Is there anything else that you brought with you to the deposition today?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Yes.  I brought my CV or a copy of my CV and my report, which I authored in September of 2018.  In addition the medical records I brought, which I reviewed and cited I think in my report from 2016 and '17.  And then recently was provided with a death certificate as well.  So I brought all those things with me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you prepare any notes in preparation for your deposition today?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So in addition to the deposition volumes, the medical record and Mr. Drummond's death certificate, were you given any other factual information about the substance of the Drummond case from counsel or anyone else that formed the basis of any of your opinions?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And, Dr. Howard, are you being compensated for your work on the Drummond case?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: I expect to be.  I've not rendered a bill.  But I would certainly expect to be for the work that I've done in this case as well as today's session.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is your hourly rate?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Do you have an approximation of how many hours you've worked on the Drummond case?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Yes.  Prior to and including my creation of the report in September of '18, I had spent seven hours on the case.  And since then I've spent an hour rereviewing the materials I mentioned to you and then a 15 minute conference with Mr. Speziali.  So I think it's eight hours and a quarter.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you asked to give any medical causation opinions in this case?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: I haven't actually been asked anything specific other than what I mentioned.  But I would expect that one of the two parties would ask me if I thought this was an asbestos related mesothelioma and I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any additional medical causation opinions in addition to the opinion you just expressed that this is an asbestos related mesothelioma?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, I have nothing prepared to cite and again I haven't been asked any questions.  But, typically, I would expect that there would be questions about -- and I actually referred to this within my report certainly that this case like many I believe in this era at least is typically related to remote asbestos exposure in the workplace. And both historically and currently I think there's a wealth of information supporting a fiber differential in that causation and I would expect to reflect on the Navy's use and knowledge about asbestos throughout the historical period of time of probably the 1940s through at least OSHA in 1972. So I would expect again I don't have any specific script to tell you what my exact opinions are there, but I would welcome any questions concerning that. I would -- I cited as best I could the variables that I and most physicians and medical scientist look to to try to establish causation in terms of the nature of the exposure, specifically the frequency, the intensity, the duration, the product itself in terms of the friability or respirability of the asbestos contained within that product.  And I certainly look to all those in trying to establish a specific causation. As I noted in this case from the deposition testimony, specifically regarding Westinghouse and GE, I thought there were very few of those specifics that were able to be cited.  So I mention that in the report. Certainly, if there's other information regarding that, I would factor all that in.  So I don't know if that answers your question globally at least.  I would expect to have a lot of opinions regarding that general area based on primarily the deposition testimony or more importantly the historical medical literature and how it developed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So looking at your report that's dated September 14th, 2018, how did this report come to be prepared?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: So I need to clarify.  The report that I believe I rendered in this case was authored on September 11th.  Is that -- are we looking at the same report?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's correct.  It was served on September 14th, so that was the date I was representing. But you're correct, the report is dated September 11th.
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Oh, I see.  Okay.  So if I understand your question, I put together this information and tried to summarize not only case specific details, which are relatively few as you probably noted, it's probably two or three paragraphs based on the deposition testimony and then at the end I insert information that I gleaned from review of the medical records. And then I have already prepared a summary report of my state of the art opinions, which of course do not change with a given case.  So I insert all of those and then submit it.  Is that what you're asking me? I'm not sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any updates to this report since you initially created it in September of 2018?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: I think, and I'm sorry, Leah, I don't know the exact date, but it seems to me that I updated my generic report for both Westinghouse and GE, which of course are not focused on Mr. Drummond's specific case, but some of that information would come from those updated reports. Which if I'm correct, I think was at the end of '18 and beginning of '19 I think.  I'd have to check.  I didn't bring those reports with me. So there may have been some updates, but I don't think any of it would conflict with the substance of this report.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I would like to mark your report as Exhibit 1 to the deposition so we know what we're referring to.
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: (Plaintiff's Exhibit No. 1 was Marked for Identification.)
So am I understanding you correctly that none of your opinions as to GE or Westinghouse has changed since this report was drafted?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you estimate giving any state of the art opinions that are not included in this report?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: I certainly don't anticipate it.  I try in these summary reports to address most, if not all, of the issues that I would expect to be asked about. Having said that, I know I've been in situations where either plaintiff or defense counsel have asked me specific questions that I might know about historically for example that I didn't include.  So if that came up, I would hope to be able to answer the question.  But I've tried the best I could to summarize all that I would expect to be asked about in this report.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Leah, this is Dave Speziali.  I can send you, if you gave me an e-mail address, I call them generic reports.  There were updates to those.  If you'd like, I can get them to you now or later at some point or through Cathy.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: Okay.  If you wouldn't mind e-mailing, that would be great.
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: I think is your e-mail available on your website?  If it is, I'll just get it from there.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: It is.
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Go ahead.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: Cathy has it as well.
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: All right.  I'll find it.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: All right.  Thank you.
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: So from reading the materials that you were provided in this case, is it your understanding that Mr. Drummond was suffering from pleural mesothelioma?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Yes.  I think he had a variety of medical conditions, but pertinent most to our discussion today is that he developed a malignant pleural mesothelioma, which I believe was likely related to past occupational exposure to asbestos.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you just touched on, as mentioned in your report, a number of variables that need to be considered when determining the degree to which a given exposure contributes to an asbestos related disease.  Is that correct?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And some of these factors that you mentioned include the proximity of exposure, duration of exposure, frequency, fiber type and there are several others listed in the report that you frequently mention.  Correct?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So after reading Mr. Drummond's deposition and reviewing his medical records, do you have any opinions regarding the variables during his work at the Fore River Shipyard in general?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, I believe certainly in his early years of employment from '56 through probably '71 I read about working in a shipyard arena, which certainly I think would provide opportunities for exposure. My earlier comments about GE and Westinghouse just had to do with a lack of very specific recollection of those variables including whether asbestos was involved and things like that. But I think from his description and my knowledge of the shipyard setting, especially in the early years, I think without giving you exact references, I took from it there were certainly opportunities for exposure in the shipyard that would have led and did lead in my opinion to the conclusion that I expressed earlier that it was likely related to asbestos.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were there any specific exposures that you were able to identify that contributed to his mesothelioma?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: As I pointed out in the report and I'll answer up front no is the answer in that many of those details are lacking. But, again, knowing the extensive use and the period of time that he was there and the description that he gave, I think generally it's fair to conclude that the general exposure through that arena would have been enough to attribute the causation conclusion too that I mentioned.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you have any opinions regarding any particular product or manufacturer's responsibility for Mr. Drummond's development of mesothelioma?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, certainly not specific manufacturers. But, again, as I rendered in the report, most pleural mesothelioma currently have to do with remote exposure, which often involves thermal insulation. I mentioned other types of exposure in the report, but the vast majority have to do with thermal insulation products. So, generally, again knowing the extensive use of those in the shipyard setting, especially in the 50s, I would say that that as a product is the most likely. But as far as a specific exposure I don't think that you can accurately conclude that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In addition to thermal insulation, are there any other products in this case that you believe may have contributed to Mr. Drummond's mesothelioma?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, my focus again was on GE and Westinghouse.  I can't -- and especially I didn't review a year after I rendered the report those other types of exposures.  I mentioned certainly brake and I think drywall in my report, but I can't recall any specific product or type of product. Thermal insulation overwhelmingly is the most likely.  I know he mentioned gaskets and other things in the shipyard, but, as I recall, overwhelmingly it was thermal insulation that I thought was the culprit.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did your review of Mr. Drummond's deposition suggest to you one way or the other that he was exposed to asbestos while working around General Electric equipment?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: No.  Again, I thought he did not recall specific exposure.  He made it very clear he didn't work -- he never worked directly on turbines.  The turbine manufacturers that he was able to recall I didn't see was specific to General Electric or Westinghouse. The specific recollection on Westinghouse regarding forced draft blowers, I think even when questioned he couldn't specifically say it was asbestos. And in my experience many of those are not insulated. So I thought there were many variables there that would not allow me to specifically conclude that exposure to Westinghouse or GE products were the culprit, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did either Westinghouse or General Electric provide you any documents regarding the insulation, thermal insulation products that were used on the Sherman-class destroyers built at the Fore River Shipyard?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you provided with any information about the asbestos content of the insulation used on this turbine on the Sherman-class destroyers?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: No, certainly not.  I'm aware generally of various manufacturers and generally of the content, but not specifically in this case, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So same question for the forced draft blowers, were you provided with any information about the asbestos content of insulation used on the forced draft blowers on the Sherman-class destroyers?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: No, just the uncertainty mentioned in the deposition.  So other than that, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  What is your general understanding of the insulation used on those types of equipment on Navy vessels during the 1950s?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, I'm certain that's out of my field of expertise, but I've seen descriptions from a variety of sources that primarily focuses on the piping that could be attached to the turbine.  Oftentimes there is a blanket referenced on the top of the turbine.  But we're getting beyond my field of expertise. I would refer to his description of the process and then certainly my knowledge of extensive use on piping within the vessel typically in shipyards historically.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If you were provided any information showing that the insulation on General Electric or Westinghouse equipment on the Sherman-class destroyers was asbestos containing, would that in any way change your opinion regarding Mr. Drummond's exposure?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, if I understand your question, it would involve that specific exposure that he experienced.  So I did mention in my report that, for example, if you were to provide evidence that his exposure on that vessel and that turbine involved asbestos containing thermal insulation and there was evidence of all those other variables in terms of more than just walking by, he was actually there when exposure was ongoing, I think from his description I'm confident that at most it would have been bystander exposure. But, historically, certainly if that was present and it was asbestos containing thermal insulation, then I would certainly be able to conclude that that might have added to the causative exposures that he experienced.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In your report you detail a number of general state of the art opinions.  And I don't want to go through all those because I think they're laid out pretty well in your report. But do you have any additional opinions about the general state of the art that are not included in your report?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: So I understood your previous question to be similar.  And, again, I don't think so, but certainly if you ask me something that was outside of this -- of what was covered here and I knew about it, I would certainly try to answer that. But I don't anticipate -- I think I've tried to cover from my knowledge and my experience what questions are most pertinent to both sides.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any opinions specific to the Navy knowledge regarding the hazards of asbestos in the 1950s?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, I don't consider myself a Navy expert. I'm not a Navy veteran, I've never worked for the Navy in a shipyard.  So in that regard, no. But I've tried to include in my report based predominately on published medical literature I believe the sophistication of the Navy in the development of this so called state of the art knowledge base. From the very beginning I cited the Fleischer Drinker report for example and then Captain Brown's publication both in the 40s that detail I think processes that the Navy had in place to try to address asbestos. And so I would -- I think I referenced what I'm thinking of in response to your question in the report and I would expect to reflect on those publications, Fleischer Drinker, the Brown publication, the Marr publication all referenced I think in my report. You know, certainly the Navy was involved with Walsh-Healy requirements, the minimum standards I referenced.  So off the top I'm thinking that those are all in response to what I would expect to render concerning your question about Navy knowledge.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any information specific to Bethlehem Steel's knowledge regarding the hazards of asbestos in the 1950s?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When Mr. Drummond began working at the Fore River Shipyard in 1956, what was the general state of the art at that time?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, as I initiated in my report, the knowledge base I believe regarding the potential hazards of asbestos began prior to that in the 1930s, late 20s if you look at case reports. So certainly by the 50s there was a base of medical literature that utilized peer review published epidemiologic studies showing in predominately textile factory arenas that with prolonged and intense and direct exposure some of those individuals would develop scarring within the lung, which was referred to as asbestosis. Certainly, I think your question was in the 50s by.  By the 40s we now have both Captain Brown's publication and maybe more importantly the Fleischer Drinker study published in '46 that indicated a number of processes were in place. And the significance of the Fleischer Drinker study I believe was that it represented the first epidemiologic study outside of the textile factory arena that concluded in part that this field of marine insulation at that time with those processes in place was not a dangerous occupation. Certainly, the state of the art at that time also involved the role of the ACGIH and the utilization of some of those studies from the 30s to initiate a dust control level that was established and promulgated across the country to try to void and prevent any adverse outcome, which as noted at that time was asbestosis. So that gets us I think to the 50s, which is I think where you asked me.  So by 1956 certainly it was acknowledged that in certain circumstances asbestos could result in scarring of the lung and there were efforts to minimize dust production at least to that level that was promulgated as a level that below which adverse outcomes would not occur.  All of that was in place by the 1950s.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: These efforts to minimize dust production levels, what were some of those efforts that were in place in the 1950s?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, when you read the publications, both the Brown publication that I mentioned in 1941, as well as the Fleischer Drinker study in 1946, they especially specific to this case they talk about processes that the Navy had in various locations and with various levels of compliance that involved ventilation, dust suppression techniques and even the use of respirator type devices. In some they mentioned wet methods, which would be occasionally utilized.  I think those are predominately the engineering categories that are cited at that time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any knowledge whether or not any of those dust minimization efforts that you just described were being used at the Fore River Shipyard?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: I certainly don't have any personal knowledge. I would reflect -- and I haven't done this in preparation for this so I can't cite it directly, but as I mentioned in my report the Fore River Shipyard was one of those surveyed by the Fleischer Drinker study. So to specifically answer I would have to look at the language there, but I don't know off the top I'm sorry.  And I'm not suggesting that those measures were preventative to the subsequent development of a mesothelioma, the knowledge of that of course comes in the future well beyond 1956 in my opinion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In your reading of Mr. Drummond's deposition testimony, did you see any indication that any of those dust suppression techniques were being used at Fore River during Mr. Drummond's time there?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: No.  But I don't recall anybody specifically asking him about ventilation and things like that.  But to answer your question, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any information regarding General Electric or Westinghouse's contemporaneous knowledge of awareness, knowledge or awareness, excuse me, of what Bethlehem Steel knew about the hazards of asbestos during Mr. Drummond's time there?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Specifically regarding Bethlehem Steel, absolutely not.  I do have some knowledge and certainly expectations regarding the published medical literature and what I would expect and in some cases know that the corporation would know about that information certainly being part of organizations which promulgate those conclusions from the published literature I think is evident in this case. And maybe this is getting too far afield, but certainly my knowledge about Alice Hamilton and her role with GE historically would I think partially address that.  But I have no knowledge about what the corporate knowledge about Bethlehem Steel's knowledge would be, it would be more aimed at the published medical literature.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In your report you express an opinion that, trying to find the correct paragraph here:  "The absence of caution labels associated with General Electric or Westinghouse cannot be deemed a proximate cause of Mr. Drummond's exposure to asbestos." Do you see that reference?  I think it's on the third page.
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: I don't -- let me see if I can find it.  I recall the reference, let's see if I can find it.  I may not need to find it.  Go ahead and ask.  I recall the reference.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The question is what is the basis for your opinion?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, so specifically regarding whether warning labels on a GE or a Westinghouse product in this case would have probably changed anybody's behavior. In most cases I don't have a specific quote from the plaintiff.  In this case Mr. Drummond was specifically asked whether or not that information would have changed him and I think I included that in my report.  He clearly stated that it would not. In most cases my conclusion, and in this one as well, is in part based on a number of variables including their described work. So the fact that he didn't work directly on those products, along with the fact that the products in question here are predominately thermal insulation as noted throughout a period of time that he worked in that arena did have warnings on them.  As well as certainly the sophistication and the knowledge of the Navy, which I referenced earlier. It wouldn't have been that that kind of information would have educated the Navy or likely based on his own response have any impact on what Mr. Drummond's activity was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that your opinion the same opinion regarding what you just testified for the Navy, is it also your opinion that these warning labels would not have impacted the shipyard in any manner?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Correct, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So is it your opinion that neither GE or Westinghouse made an affirmative decision not to warn because they were aware of the shipyard or the Navy's investigation regarding the hazards of asbestos?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, I can't really speak specifically to what was underneath that decision, but certainly they were aware and in many instances it would be based again on published medical literature, as well as experience, that number one as I think was pointed out in a deposition the forced draft blowers and in this case the turbines would typically be delivered without asbestos. The asbestos that the Navy decided to subsequently apply would have in many cases had warnings already on it. So in part that knowledge of the processes that are in place and probably that many products that were available and in use at that time, which were I don't believe mandated to use, did have warning labels already on them. So I think speculating a little bit that all of those factors would certainly play into that decision, as well as the fact that your product does not contain asbestos.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you mentioned some of the controls that were in place affecting shipyards during this time period.  And I believe you cited to the minimum requirements for safety of industrial health for shipyards in the Walsh-Healey Act. Are there any other that apply specifically to the Fore River Shipyard during that time period?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, certainly the ACGIH.  And I guess not a requirement, but my understanding is that the vast majority of states embraced the recommended threshold limit value.  So what the legal requirement of specific shipyard was regarding that I can't really address, but I think that also would at least speak to the processes in place. Other than that, I think the two things that you mentioned certainly are pertinent to that.  Along with certainly the published literature that I spoke to earlier.  That's somewhat of a unique variable in this case.  So I think that's all I'm thinking of in answering that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And specific to the Walsh-Healey Act, was that applicable to product manufacturers such as General Electric and Westinghouse as well as shipyards?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: We're getting outside of my field here.  My understanding is a federal employee was Walsh-Healy Act involved federal contracts beyond a certain economic level and then it required a variety of actions be taken, which included adherence to the five million particle per cubic foot level in the 50s I recall. But as far as specific requirements and legal requirements of a corporation versus a shipyard, I don't know.  My understanding as a physician was that it applied to all federal contracts over a certain dollar amount.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so the federal contract, is it your understanding that was just between the Navy and a shipyard and not necessarily including product manufacturers?  I'm just trying to understand your opinion.
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Okay.  Again, I'm not an expert on the contractual situation.  My understanding was if you signed a federal contract, whoever you are, General Electric, Westinghouse or a shipyard that involved more than I thought it was $10,000, but I'm not sure of that, then you would be obligated to follow this -- these rules of engagement.  That's the extent of my knowledge. I just know from reading it that it embraced the five million particle which becomes very pertinent to what I testify about speaking again to the widespread adoption both in federal and in state jurisdictions to that level as being a credible effort to do the best that we could with the knowledge that we had at a specific time to prevent adverse outcomes.  That's the extent of my knowledge of that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In what way do the requirements imposed upon the Fore River Shipyard through the Walsh-Healey Act or the minimum standards contribute to your opinion that the Fore River Shipyard was highly sophisticated regarding asbestos safety?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, my understanding of your previous question that led to that label of highly sophisticated had to do with the Navy. The shipyard in terms of the Walsh-Healey Act in my opinion it speaks to the question that frequently comes up about the legitimacy of the five million particle per cubic foot level. Clearly people were not embracing that in an effort to cause harm to people.  And when that position is taken, I think citing federal endorsement of it through the Walsh-Healey Act and then state endorsement of it tends to minimize the legitimacy of that argument. So beyond that, the legal sophistication of the shipyard I'm not personally aware of.  I was speaking primarily of where the Navy's involvement from the very beginning of this period of time, specifically the 40s, in investigating and knowing about the potential hazards of asbestos.

Usually, if the Navy is not involved, I've done the work to try to figure out what the corporate entity was guided by in a given state.  I'm just assuming in this case there was heavy Navy involvement.  He made that clear from his testimony as well.  So that's kind of where my thought process is regarding the sophistication.

I would certainly expect them to know about that.

speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: I usually don't get that from the medical records.  But there are some variables that I look to and in this case there was evidence of pleural plaques formation, which also attests to the deposition claim of occupational exposure to asbestos. So specific to this case that was an indicator in my opinion supportive of Mr. Drummond's testimony and what I knew about the workplace that supported that this was an asbestos related mesothelioma. But most of the time and in most situations regarding your question, it's gleaned more from the deposition testimony of the workplace and the exposure than it is the medical record.  I, you know, with mesothelioma many are non occupational -- non occupationally related, but you can't determine that in most cases from the medical records.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you see anything in your review of Mr. Drummond's medical records that you disagreed with treatment wise, diagnosis wise or anything just in general that you disagreed with?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

The only thing I can think of, and I don't think it was a conclusion, but one of the entries listed a history of asbestosis and that certainly was not supported throughout his clinical record that I reviewed. That was not a diagnosis that his treating physicians had reached. But that was just one entry, it was in a list of historical diagnosis so I wouldn't know what they had based that on.  And it certainly was not supported by his clinical records.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: No, not the ones that I reviewed.  No, they did not.  That is noted on a death certificate, but there are other significant inaccuracies in the death certificate. So I think the clinical records did not conclude that he had asbestosis.  They did include that he had mesothelioma of course.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In your review of the death certificate, what are the inaccuracies in your opinion?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And why is that?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Well, hopefully we can agree here today that lung cancer is not mesothelioma.  They are totally distinct entities that really have little, if anything, to do with each other.  So I saw nothing in his record that this gentleman had had lung cancer. And, again, asbestosis is a diagnosis based on a variety of things, predominately the radiographic findings and the radiographic reports that I saw along with the clinical conclusions by his treating doctors did not diagnose him with that.  So those are the two most glaring ones. I guess from your perspective I would conclude that the absence of mesothelioma on his death certificate is an obvious error as well in my opinion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is it your opinion that neither the Navy or Bethlehem Steel appreciated the risk of exposure to bystanders during the time period that Mr. Drummond worked at the Fore River Shipyard?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

text: Objection to form.  Go ahead, Doc.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: So, again, I don't know the specific basis for Bethlehem Steel.  I would expect everybody to look to the medical literature to try to answer that. Certainly, in terms of exposure, I think there would be general understanding, which is not unique to asbestos, that certainly there is likely to be exposure. The question certainly has to do with the expected development of adverse outcomes and that throughout this period of time was felt not to occur if the level of exposure was be below a certain range. And certainly at this point, '56 to '62 in particular, I don't know of any epidemiologic based knowledge that would in any way suggest bystanders were at risk of disease.  I think there would be just a general understanding that there might be minimal exposure the further you get from a focal point. But, again, the point of dust production, the target was five million particles and below that adverse effects would not occur. So clearly it was not perceived nor reported that bystanders were at risk of getting any disease, especially mesothelioma.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so that risk, therefore, would not have been appreciated by either the Navy or Bethlehem Steel?
speaker: MS. MCMORRIS

I would expect and certainly from all the processes in place with the Navy they were aware that there was a risk of exposure, but not a risk of disease to bystanders at that period of time.

text: Okay.

For the time period for the activities described by Mr. Drummond and as you reflected in your report and your testimony today, would there have been reason for General Electric or Westinghouse to know or have reason or belief that exposure to asbestos insulation materials in conjunction with those products would have been dangerous for Mr. Drummond during the timeframes we're talking about?
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: No.  And I was trying to answer that with Leah's last question I think.  Certainly the state of the art at that period of time '56 through '62 was clearly not that a bystander, if in fact that occurred, the type of exposure to thermal insulation was likely to cause any adverse outcome.  So no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And let's again just for purposes of this question -- and I understand your opinions, and I understand why your -- when you say through '62, you're focusing on Mr. Drummond's apprenticeship years; is that right?
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: Yes.  There was a little bit of confusion beyond that because it was active military career.  But that's why I chose that period of time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And that's fine.  But let's just assume for purposes of our discussion so that there is no question as to where your opinions stand, we know that his career went through '71 and I recognize that his testimony differs substantially from his apprentice years to his later years. But if we expanded the question to include the period up through '71, in that timeframe again is there any reason to believe or know that the types of exposures that he describes would have created dangers for him in terms of insulation materials on the General Electric or Westinghouse products discussed in this case?
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: No.  He made it clear that at most we're talking about what most of us would refer to as bystander type exposure.  So he's not the one involved in insulating for example. But if there was thermal insulation involved in these exposures that it contained asbestos and he was exposed in a bystander fashion, then to answer your question through '71 for sure bystanders were not perceived to be likely or at risk of developing disease. Many publications said in that time period that there are others who may experience exposures, but until we know that exposure is a problem or above a level that is considered a problem, it would be inaccurate to assume or conclude that all of those people are at risk of disease.  Certainly there would be some other who are exposed. And this concept is not at all unique to asbestos.  It's a dose response relationship that applies to just about any product or element.  Oxygen is always the one I think about when asked that question.  But dose response means that just because you have some exposure, which by the way all of us have had, that does not mean that you have a higher incidence of disease because of that exposure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And in at least through '71, what was the prevailing threshold limit value that was -- that was established for asbestos through that timeframe?
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: So throughout that time period starting actually in the 1940s, the threshold limit value was five million particles per cubic foot. At the very end of the time period that you're asking me about, there were suggestions by some to alter the TLV and that occurred I believe in the late '71, early '72 time period. Now that was multifactorial in part related to a change in the methodology for measuring dust rather than particles going to fibers.  But it was also based on developing literature that showed that the threshold limit value may need to be reduced, which of course it was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

I mentioned Captain Brown's publication as well in the 40s and then Marr's publication in '64. Those all come to mind immediately when you ask that question in that we have a variety of processes allegedly utilized by the Navy and reported in the medical literature that would suggest that communication, if you will, that there is a potential in addressing this fiber or these products and that has to be communicated in order for -- for this to be taking place, which is published. So in addition to the published medical literature, you know, the involvement of the National Safety Council, the ACGIH, the minimum standards that we talked about, all of these to me would support the idea that processes are utilized, which would require that communication. Not that I would expect the individual sailor to know specifics about the diseases in question or anything like that, but that would communicate some of the potential for hazard, which I think you can assume has to take place.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So you mentioned three publications, you mentioned the Brown publication 1941, the Fleischer Drinker report of 1946, the Marr study of 1964.  There was also discussions of the Walsh-Healey Act.  So let's just focus on those four publications. If in fact Mr. Drummond was working either with or around asbestos insulation materials in the manner in which he described in association with Westinghouse or General Electric products or equipment, if he was doing that during the timeframe in question, would there -- would he have been advised or received information regarding respiratory protection as to asbestos if he was in danger from those exposures based on what was published?  I'm not saying it happened, based on what the Navy was telling the world.

text: Well, and I may need some help in understanding this. The risk was focused especially in the 60s as we've mentioned on insulators.  So insulators and when you read the Fleischer Drinker study it has to do with marine insulators, are encouraged to utilize a variety of measures including respiratory protection. Now from my reading of these deposition volumes, I saw no evidence that Mr. Drummond was an insulator.  So I think we've agreed that at best or at the worst he was a bystander.  And, therefore, the advice at that time would not be that if you're a bystander, A, you're at risk of getting a disease, especially something like mesothelioma and, B, that you as a bystander would be asked to wear respirators.
